description: Noun from Middle English schade, from Old English sċeadu, sċadu (“shadow; shade”), from Proto-West Germanic *skadu, from Proto-Germanic *skadwaz (“shadow; shade”). More at shadow.
Verb from Old English sceadwian, derived from sċeadu, above.

nouns.description: Noun from Middle English schade, from Old English sċeadu, sċadu (“shadow; shade”), from Proto-West Germanic *skadu, from Proto-Germanic *skadwaz (“shadow; shade”). More at shadow. Verb from Old English sceadwian, derived from sċeadu, above.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) Darkness where light, particularly sunlight, is blocked.
examples: The old oak tree gave shade in the heat of the day.

entries.meaning: (countable) Something that blocks light, particularly in a window.
examples: Close the shade, please: it's too bright in here.

entries.meaning: (countable) A variety of a colour/color, in particular one obtained by adding black (compare tint).
examples: I've painted my room in five lovely shades of pink and chartreuse.

entries.meaning: (figuratively) A subtle variation in a concept.
examples: shades of meaning

entries.meaning: (figuratively) An aspect that is reminiscent of something.
examples: shades of Groucho

entries.meaning: A very small degree of a quantity, or variety of meaning
examples: Mrs. Rhodes who (so I gathered from Mr. Petherick's careful language) was perhaps just a shade of a hypochondriac, had retired to bed immediately after dinner.

entries.meaning: (chiefly literary and fantasy) A ghost or specter; a spirit.
examples: Too long have I been haunted by that shade.
The adventurer was attacked by a shade.

entries.meaning: (countable) A postage stamp showing an obvious difference in colour/color to the original printing and needing a separate catalogue/catalog entry.
(uncountable, originally gay slang) Subtle insults.
examples: throw shade
Why did you paint your room chartreuse? No shade; I'm genuinely curious.

entries.meaning: (countable) A cover around or above a light bulb, a lampshade.
(historical) A candle-shade.
examples: I am now finishing this letter by candle-light, with the help of a handkerchief tied over the shade.

verbs.description: Noun from Middle English schade, from Old English sċeadu, sċadu (“shadow; shade”), from Proto-West Germanic *skadu, from Proto-Germanic *skadwaz (“shadow; shade”). More at shadow. Verb from Old English sceadwian, derived from sċeadu, above.
shade (third-person singular simple present shades, present participle shading, simple past and past participle shaded)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To shield (someone or something) from light.
examples: The old oak tree shaded the lawn in the heat of the day.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, rare) To shield oneself from light.
examples: We shaded under a huge oak tree.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To alter slightly.
examples: You'll need to shade your shot slightly to the left.
Most politicians will shade the truth if it helps them.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To vary or approach something slightly, particularly in color.
examples: The hillside was bright green, shading towards gold in the drier areas.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, baseball, of a defensive player) To move slightly from one's normal fielding position.
examples: Jones will shade a little to the right on this pitch count.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To darken, particularly in drawing.
examples: I draw contours first, gradually shading in midtones and shadows.

entries.meaning: To surpass by a narrow margin.
examples: Both parties claimed afterwards that their man did best in the debate, but an early opinion poll suggested Mr Cameron shaded it.

entries.meaning: (transitive, graphical user interface) To reduce (a window) so that only its title bar is visible.
examples: Antonym: unshade

entries.meaning: (transitive, slang) To throw shade, to subtly insult someone.
(transitive, obsolete) To shelter; to cover from injury; to protect; to screen.
(transitive, obsolete) To present a shadow or image of; to shadow forth; to represent.
